title: How Protopica uses remix and blend in Sora
summary: In this transcript chunk, the speaker introduces a new protop short project involving reshaping their entire workflow using Sora. They discuss the concept of remixing, where they can swap characters between different universes in their videos. The process involves using remix to swap elements in a video and blend to create a transition between two clips. To use remix, one can click on a generated video or upload their own shot and make changes like swapping a baby inside a grandmother. Blend allows for smoothly transitioning between two clips by selecting the first clip, clicking on blend, and choosing the next one.

The models are available at varying costs and were demonstrated to easily convert text-based agents into voice agents with minimal code changes. title: Stop ChatGPT from interrupting you üôÑ

title: üí¨ ChatGPT's Team Responds to Your Advanced Voice Questions #Shorts
summary: The speaker, Rocky, is discussing improvements being made to the Chach PT iOS app's speech recognition model. The model currently responds to background noise as speech, leading to interruptions during conversations. The team is working on filtering out this noise to focus more effectively on user speech. They are also exploring ways to help the model understand when a user is done speaking to allow for a more natural conversation flow. Users can access a voice isolation mic mode on their iPhones to prioritize their voice and block out ambient noise while using Chach GPT. The app also allows users to pause the model's responses by pressing anywhere on the screen until they lift their finger. These features are currently available only on iOS, but Android support is coming soon. Feedback is encouraged to help improve the app further.

title: 21-year old dev destroys LeetCode, gets kicked out of school...
summary: Roy, a 21-year-old student at Columbia University, was expelled for creating a JavaScript application that helps users ace technical interviews. The app uses AI to guide users through technical questions in real-time during video calls. Roy used the app to secure job offers from major companies like Meta, TikTok, Capital One, and Amazon, causing the offers to be rescinded. The app helps users cheat by generating realistic solutions to interview questions, bypassing cheating detection software. Despite the controversy, Roy's success with the app demonstrates flaws in the technical interview process. While denouncing cheating, the transcript also acknowledges the pressure and impracticality of technical interview prep. Roy's expulsion from Columbia highlights the consequences of his actions, but also hints at his potential for success in the tech industry. The transcript emphasizes the importance of mastering programming skills and promotes Brilliant, an interactive learning platform for understanding deep learning and AI technology.

title: The "vibe coding" mind virus explained‚Ä¶
summary: In March 2025, the programming world was affected by a "vibe coding mind virus" trend. This trend involves fully embracing the vibes and forgetting about the code. The concept was popularized by exopi wizard Andrey. One example mentioned is an indie hacker named Peter Levelvels who successfully monetized a real-time flight simulator MMO using vibe coding. However, there are concerns that this trend is leading to the proliferation of low-quality content on the internet. The CEO of Anthropic predicts that AI will be responsible for writing most code within the next 12 months. The transcript also highlights the differences between coding and programming, with emphasis on the importance of creativity and experience in programming. It warns about the potential pitfalls of vibe coding without a deep understanding of the code. The transcript also suggests using tools like Vzero, Bolt, Cursor, and Windserve to enhance the vibe coding process. Following three rules - choosing a popular tech stack, mastering version control with git, and breaking down requirements for AI - are recommended for successful vibe coding. The importance of Grammarly as a writing tool for professionals is also highlighted.

title: Next.js rocked by critical 9.1 level exploit...
summary: The transcript discusses a critical security advisory affecting the popular JavaScript framework Next.js, where an exploit allows attackers to bypass authentication and authorization in Next.js middleware. This issue has caused a stir among React and Next.js critics, with companies like Cloudflare leveraging it to attract customers away from Versel. If you have a Next.js app in production that hasn't been updated, you may be at risk. The exploit involves manipulating middleware headers, posing a serious threat to websites that rely on middleware for authorization. The delay in patching this issue has drawn criticism, with some attempting to capitalize on it for marketing purposes. The conversation between Versel and Cloudflare CEOs on social media has escalated into a spat, causing drama in the tech community. The transcript also mentions Hostinger, a provider of Linux servers, as an alternative hosting solution with options for hosting frameworks like Next.js securely.

title: Microsoft goes nuclear on TypeScript codebase‚Ä¶
summary: Microsoft announced a complete rewrite of the TypeScript programming language, which is a crucial project in web development. The TypeScript language itself is written in TypeScript, which is not optimized for building TypeScript. Surprisingly, Microsoft chose to rewrite TypeScript in Go, a language developed by Google, despite other language options like C++ or Rust. The switch to Go made the compiler 10 times faster, improving performance in big projects and VS Code. The decision to use Go was driven by its compilation to optimized machine code, automatic memory management, and portability. The new compiler is expected to be released around TypeScript 7, preserving the behavior and semantics of the original code. Despite some initial challenges, Microsoft's choice to use Go has been commended for prioritizing the best tool for the job.

title: Our AI girlfriends just leveled up big time‚Ä¶

The conversation also touches on the technical details behind these AI tools and their functionalities. The discussion explores the potential applications of such AI models, including humanoid robots like Protolone. title: TikTok just released its React Native killer‚Ä¶
summary: A new JavaScript framework called Lynx was recently released by ByteDance, the company behind TikTok. Lynx is an open-source multi-platform app development framework that aims to provide smoother UIs and faster launch times compared to other cross-platform tools like React Native and Flutter. It features a dual-threaded architecture and allows developers to build iOS and Android apps with JavaScript. Lynx is already being used in high-traffic apps at TikTok. It uses a dual-threaded architecture, with the main thread powered by Prim JS and the user code running on a separate thread to improve performance. Lynx is framework agnostic and supports native CSS features for styling. Although Lynx shows promise, it currently lacks an established ecosystem and tools like Expo or a massive widget library. The summary also covers the experience of trying out Lynx, which involves using the RS pack module bundler and observing that the framework allows for using regular CSS for styling native elements. The summary ends with a mention of Code Rabbit, an AI co-pilot for code reviews that was sponsored in the video. Overall, Lynx shows potential but may require developers to rewrite existing code to adopt the new framework.

title: I replaced my entire tech stack with Postgres...
summary: The speaker criticizes modern web development, pointing out the proliferation of various tools and services that can become costly and complicated. They suggest that PostgreSQL alone can fulfill 90% of web development needs. PostgreSQL offers advanced data types and extensibility, allowing developers to achieve unique functionalities without relying on multiple external tools. Various extensions like PG Cron, PG Vector, and PG JWT are discussed, showcasing how PostgreSQL can handle tasks typically associated with other specialized services. The speaker also mentions services like Postgres on a serverless platform provided by Neon, making it easier to work with PostgreSQL. Finally, the speaker recommends tools like PG mooncake and PostgREST for additional functionalities like time series data storage and automatic API generation from a PostgreSQL database, respectively.

title: Microsoft‚Äôs new chip looks like science fiction‚Ä¶
summary: Microsoft has announced a new Quantum Computing chip named Myer on a one which claims to have created an entirely new state of matter called the "Topo computer". This technology could potentially revolutionize computing by allowing for millions of cubits, making computers billions of times faster than current technology. The chip is based on the myron a fon subatomic particle, which is resistant to decoherence, a common issue in quantum computing. Microsoft's approach is different from Google and IBM, and if successful, could change the world of computing. The chip needs to be kept at near absolute zero temperatures, and although Microsoft claims it can scale up to millions of cubits, this has not been achieved yet. Microsoft's topological approach may require programmers to rewrite code to optimize for Quantum hardware. A tool called Code Rabbit is recommended for code reviews, offering AI assistance for optimizing code.

title: Elon Musk attempts hostile takeover of OpenAI‚Ä¶
summary: Elon Musk has launched a hostile takeover bid for OpenAI, offering to buy the nonprofit organization for $97.4 billion. OpenAI's co-founder, Sam Altman, declined the offer and made a counteroffer to buy Twitter. Musk referred to Altman as a "swindler" and made a new nickname for him, "scam Altman." This move is seen as part of Musk's strategy to gain control over artificial intelligence, a critical piece in his quest for total world domination. OpenAI is transitioning to a for-profit structure, which Musk opposes as he previously donated to the organization when it was a nonprofit. Musk's offer only focuses on the nonprofit entity, which OpenAI values at $40 billion. The deal would complicate OpenAI's transition to for-profit and its relationship with Microsoft, which is entitled to a share of future profits. The likelihood of Musk actually acquiring OpenAI is low, but the beef between Musk and Altman continues.

title: UK demands backdoor for encrypted Apple user data...
summary: The British Empire has issued a secret technical capability notice to Apple, demanding a back door to access users' encrypted iCloud data globally. This affects all Apple customers and is a threat to end-to-end encryption apps like Telegram, Signal, and WhatsApp. The Investigatory Powers Act of 2016 grants UK agencies hacking capabilities and surveillance powers. Apple's Advanced Data Protection service uses end-to-end encryption, where users manage their keys. Quantum computers are the only threat to this encryption. However, it's unlikely that Apple will comply with the demand. To protect privacy, one should use encryption for communications, full disk encryption, a trusted VPN, Tor browser, and an operating system like Tails OS. Privacy is essential and achievable through math and computer science. Brilliant, a learning platform, offers courses in these subjects.

Gemini also offers different model sizes for varying needs, with a free version available for non-developers to use in chatbots. The model has an impressive context window and excels in the LM Arena Benchmark. Gemini also offers chatbot capabilities and can handle large amounts of data. While it may not be the top choice for complex math and science tasks, Gemini shines in various web development tasks and is gaining recognition in the LM field. title: Next.js rocked by critical 9.1 level exploit...
summary: The popular JavaScript framework Next.js was recently hit by a critical security advisory on March 24th, 2025. The exploit allows attackers to bypass authentication and authorization in Next.js middleware, potentially putting apps at serious risk. This issue has led to drama and criticism, with some companies using it as an opportunity to poach customers. If you have a Next.js app that has not been upgraded, you could be vulnerable to this exploit. It's recommended to upgrade as soon as possible, especially if you are self-hosting on Versel. The exploit involves guessing and adding the name of the middleware to a header, making it easy for attackers to skip authorization logic. The bug was first reported on February 27th but was not patched until March 18th, causing frustration among developers. Some companies, like Cloudflare, tried to block the exploit but faced issues with false positives. The situation sparked drama between Cloudflare and Versel CEOs on Twitter. The video also mentions Hostinger as a provider for drama-free hosting solutions and recommends checking them out.

title: Microsoft goes nuclear on TypeScript codebase‚Ä¶
summary: Microsoft recently announced that they are reprogramming the TypeScript programming language in Go, a language developed by Google. The decision was made to address performance issues in the TypeScript compiler, resulting in 10x speed improvements. Go is a compiled language that offers automatic memory management and portability, making it a suitable choice for the rewrite. The transition from TypeScript to Go is being referred to as a port rather than a total rewrite, ensuring compatibility with existing code. The new compiler is expected to be released in TypeScript 7, offering big performance gains for developers. Despite the delay in the release, Microsoft's decision to use Go has been praised for selecting the best tool for the job. The video also promotes Sentry's Trace Explorer tool for debugging and monitoring span data in codebases.

title: TikTok just released its React Native killer‚Ä¶
summary: A new JavaScript framework called Lynx was introduced by ByteDance, the same company behind TikTok. Lynx aims to provide a high performance dual-threaded UI rendering engine for building cross-platform mobile apps with smoother UIs and faster launch times compared to other tools like React Native. This new framework is used in high traffic apps at TikTok and offers advantages such as a dual-threaded architecture to improve performance and allow for instant first frame rendering. Lynx supports various frameworks like Svelte and Vue, and enables the use of native CSS features for styling. However, the framework lacks an established ecosystem and tooling support. The transcript also mentions the usage of RS Pack for project generation, the ability to style elements using regular CSS or Tailwind, and the ease of live preview on mobile devices using the Lynx Explorer app. Overall, Lynx shows promise but may require developers to rewrite their code to leverage its capabilities.

title: I replaced my entire tech stack with Postgres...
summary: The speaker in the transcript discusses the challenges of modern web development, emphasizing the abundance of tools available, which can lead to cost and complexity issues. They propose utilizing PostgreSQL, a relational database, for a variety of web development needs, highlighting its advanced data types and extensibility. The speaker goes on to demonstrate unconventional and creative ways to leverage PostgreSQL, such as working with unstructured data using binary JSON and implementing extensions like PG Cron for scheduled tasks, a cache system in PostgreSQL, and AI capabilities using the PG Vector extension. Further examples include utilizing the TS Vector type for full-text search functionality, transforming databases into GraphQL APIs with the PG GraphQL extension, and implementing real-time features with Electric SQL. The speaker also touches on implementing user authentication and authorization using extensions like PG Crypto and PG JWT, as well as collecting analytics data with PG Mooncake. Additionally, they mention PostgREST as a tool for automatically creating a RESTful API from a PostgreSQL database. The transcript concludes with the mention of storing HTML, CSS, and JavaScript in the database and a nod to Neon as a provider of PostgreSQL on a serverless platform.

title: GPT-4.5 shocks the world with its lack of intelligence...
summary: The transcript discusses the release of GPT 4.5, which is the most expensive AI model ever produced by OpenAI. However, the model did not live up to the hype as it failed to excel in benchmarks, win awards, or offer any novel capabilities. Despite being a good model, it did not meet the expectations set by the AI community. The transcript also mentions the disappointment surrounding the release of the Epstein files and the challenges faced in the development of AI models like GPT 4.5. It touches on the high cost of GPT 4.5 and its limitations in creative thinking, programming tasks, and performance compared to other models. The transcript concludes by discussing the potential of GPT 5 and the future of AI development, as well as promoting Brilliant, a platform offering interactive lessons on deep learning and computer science.

title: Claude 3.7 goes hard for programmers‚Ä¶
summary: The transcript highlights the release of Claude 3.7 by Anthropic, a large language model that has garnered a lot of attention from programmers. The new model is described as being highly advanced and capable of outperforming other models in solving GitHub issues. Claude 3.7 comes with a new feature called Claude code, a CLI tool that allows for building, testing, and executing code within projects. The narrator describes testing the CLI tool and generating code for various tasks, showcasing its capabilities in frontend development. However, there are issues noted with Claude's generated code, such as not utilizing certain technologies specified in the prompt. The transcript also discusses the impact of AI on the labor force, with Claude potentially replacing traditional programmers. Overall, the narrator gives a detailed overview and demonstration of using Claude 3.7's CLI tool for coding tasks.

title: Microsoft‚Äôs new chip looks like science fiction‚Ä¶
summary: Microsoft has announced a new Quantum Computing chip called Myer on a one, claiming to have created an entirely new state of matter. This chip, based on the myeron a fon particle, is resistant to Quantum decoherence, potentially making quantum computers much faster and more stable. The chip operates on a nanowire and requires near absolute zero temperatures. Microsoft is the only big company pursuing this topological approach, and if successful, it could revolutionize computing, requiring programmers to adapt their code for quantum hardware. Microsoft is also promoting an AI co-pilot for code reviews called Code Rabbit, which offers feedback and suggestions for code improvements.

title: Is Elon‚Äôs Grok 3 the new AI king?
summary: The transcript discusses the release of a new large language model named Grock 3, associated with Elon Musk. The model is noted for being uncensored and controversial, able to generate content illegal in some countries. It has various capabilities, including text-to-video and plans for a subscription service called Super Grock. The transcript delves into the training and performance of Grock 3, how it compares to other models, and its unique access to Twitter data. It also mentions Elon Musk's attempt to acquire OpenAI and Mark Zuckerberg's use of pirated books for AI training. The potential impact of Grock 3 on Internet trolling is highlighted. Additionally, the transcript touches on the AI benchmarking process, the training of Grock 3 on a powerful supercomputer, and the pricing strategy for its anticipated subscription service. The transcript also promotes the sponsor Brilliant, offering educational resources on deep learning and coding.

title: Elon Musk attempts hostile takeover of OpenAI‚Ä¶
summary: Elon Musk has launched a hostile takeover bid to gain control over OpenAI for $97.4 billion, but the offer was declined by Sam Altman, who even made a counter offer to buy Twitter. Musk referred to Sam as a swindler and a scammer. Elon's offer is seen as a strategic move in his quest for total world domination, as he believes AI is a critical piece in achieving this goal. The situation is complex as OpenAI is transitioning to a for-profit structure, and there are various financial and ethical implications involved. The likelihood of Musk successfully buying OpenAI is currently low, but the rivalry between Musk and Altman is ongoing.

title: UK demands backdoor for encrypted Apple user data...
summary: The British Empire has demanded Apple to create a backdoor to access users' encrypted iCloud data globally, affecting all Apple customers. This demand comes under the Investigatory Powers Act of 2016, granting hacking capabilities to UK intelligence agencies. Apple's Advanced Data protection service uses end-to-end encryption, meaning even Apple can't access the data without the user's key. Methods to enhance privacy include using end-to-end encryption for communications, full disk encryption, a trusted VPN with a strict no logs policy, browsing on the Tor browser, and using an operating system like Tails OS. Apple is unlikely to comply with the demand, and a possible compromise may involve discontinuing Advanced Data protection for UK residents. Encouragement is given to learn about cybersecurity and encryption through resources like the Brilliant platform.

title: Google finally shipped some fire‚Ä¶
summary: Google recently released Gemini 2.0, a large language model, which has had a significant impact in the AI race. While Google has faced some setbacks in the past, Gemini is seen as a game-changer due to its cost-effectiveness and real-world applications. Gemini outperforms competitors in processing PDFs with high accuracy and at a fraction of the cost. It offers different models at varying prices, with the cheapest being over 90% more affordable than some competitors. Gemini can handle large context windows and is praised for its capabilities in natural language conversations and tasks like summarizing videos. While it may not be the best for advanced math and science work, Gemini excels in benchmarks like the LM Arena Benchmark. Google also recently open-sourced the operating system for the pebble watch and offers a family of llms called Gemma. Lastly, the transcript mentions Savola as a platform for deploying applications efficiently.

title: üî¥ Day 3 of the 5-Day AI Agent SaaS Challenge (Next.js 15, Convex, Clerk, Schematic, Stripe)
summary: Papa React aka Sunny welcomes viewers to day three of the 5-day AI agent challenge, discussing tasks like setting up databases, processing videos, and enhancing UI. He showcases prizes, encourages engagement, and emphasizes perseverance. The transcript covers feedback on design and domain purchases, setting up Schematic, integrating payment systems, and creating layouts. Discussions include token systems, video processing, feature usage, and server actions for Youtube API access. Troubleshooting Tailwind issues, image handling, and live debugging are highlighted. The speaker explains title and transcription generation steps, Convex setup for AI projects, and backend analysis page connectivity with Cluck. Plans for building an AI chat application are revealed, emphasizing community support and coding perseverance. Additionally, upcoming sessions will focus on AI chat functionalities supported by an AI agent and releasing code for free on day five.

title: üî¥ Day 2 of the 5-Day AI Agent SaaS Challenge (Next.js 15, Clerk, Schematic, Stripe)
summary: In this 5-day AI Agent SAS challenge, Papa React expresses excitement for the overwhelming interest with over 6,000 sign-ups and 3,000 homework submissions. Participants are tasked with building the AI agent SAS app features, like the landing page, authentication, schematic, and stripe integration. Additional tasks include database setup, YouTube video processing, AI agent introduction, and subscription tiers. Rewards include MacBook Pros, memberships, and SWAG packs for top performers. Participants can earn points through engagement and assistance to amplify their chances. The importance of commitment, participation, community engagement, and support is highlighted. The challenge involves setting up projects, middleware for protection, Stripe payment plans using Schematic, script generation, and UI design enhancements. Viewers are guided through setting up Stripe keys, deployment, customization, and preparation for upcoming tasks, emphasizing community support and the potential for success in the challenge.

title: Could Rockets Change the Speed of War?
summary: The US military is exploring the possibility of using rockets to transport goods around the world quickly. Currently, they rely on various modes of transportation such as trains, trucks, boats, and planes, including cargo planes like the C7 Globe Masters. Shipping goods with these methods can be time-consuming, taking days or even weeks. By using rockets, the military could potentially move 60 tons of supplies in just minutes. There have been attempts to achieve this since the 1960s, but recent advancements in reusable rocket technology have made it more feasible. Initial tests are being conducted on an abandoned atoll that is being revitalized for this purpose. Subscribe to stay updated on this ongoing program.

title: The New Way Nations are Fighting (and why it matters)
summary: The nature of war is evolving with the rise of proxy wars, where external powers support conflicts within other countries rather than engaging directly. This trend has increased, with over 25 such conflicts occurring simultaneously in 2020, reshaping geopolitics and making resolution more challenging. Historical analysis, especially during the Cold War, shows examples like the Korean War and conflicts in the Congo and Vietnam. In the post-Cold War era, powerful countries like the US and Russia engage in proxy wars to advance their interests, as seen in Afghanistan, Ukraine, Libya, Syria, and Sudan. China also plays a role in proxy conflicts but tends to avoid direct involvement. These wars are deadlier, longer-lasting, and have severe consequences for civilians caught in the middle, emphasizing the need for awareness and understanding of this prevalent form of modern conflict.

title: Why The Military Plays Games to Prepare for War
summary: The summarized text explores war game scenarios involving tensions between nations, emphasizing their significance in preparing decision-makers for real-world conflicts and the importance of understanding conflict dynamics to prevent war through strategic planning. It delves into the strategic decisions, simulated actions, historical examples, and learning outcomes of war games, ultimately highlighting the necessity of honing critical thinking skills and testing assumptions in high-stakes situations to avoid military confrontations.

title: Why Guantanamo Is Expanding
summary: The transcript talks about the construction of prison camps for migrants at Guantanamo Bay this year. The administration plans to send tens of thousands of migrants there, and the Biden Administration approved funding for this migrant jail. While Trump expanded the program, claiming that the worst criminals will be sent there, the Department of Homeland Security data shows that a third of the people going have no criminal record, indicating that criminality may not be the only priority.

title: How North Korea Pulled off a Billion $$$ Heist
summary: North Korea orchestrated the largest cryptocurrency heist in history, stealing $1.5 billion from the crypto trading platform Bitfinex. The hackers used a combination of malware, phishing, and credential theft to infiltrate the system and divert a significant amount of ethereum to their wallets. This highlights North Korea's sophisticated hacking capabilities despite its outdated appearance.

title: Where is all of the world‚Äôs gold?!
summary: Humans have mined enough gold to fill a cube measuring 22 meters on each side, which would be worth $14 trillion. Much of this gold is used in jewelry, while the rest is stored in vaults, such as the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Other countries also hold significant amounts of gold in their vaults. There are still vast deposits of gold yet to be discovered, including some under the ocean or floating as flecks in seawater. The speaker expresses interest in creating a video about gold and encourages viewers to subscribe for more content.

title: China is Building its Own ‚ÄúPentagon‚Äù (it‚Äôs HUGE)
summary: In China, a massive military command center is being constructed, resembling the size of the Pentagon but around ten times larger. The facility is believed to be deep underground, spanning approximately 4 km across, with numerous cranes working tirelessly day and night. Reinforced concrete is being used, similar to structures in the US designed to protect officials during nuclear war. This development indicates China's ambition to rival or exceed the military strength of the United States. Viewers are encouraged to stay updated on this ongoing project.
